answers.author: John Zakian
answers.text:
I have been blessed to work for local governments and nonprofits which as part of their management philosophy was to nurture and encourage knowledge and career advancement.  In all cases, it was never attached either to a minimum time or a time limit, but, rather, was an attitude of encouragement and comfort to continue to pursue opportunities.  The unspoken rule was to be careful in balancing pursuit of training opportunities with the obligations of the position.  The shared viewpoint among my employers was the knowledgement growth represented advancement in management capacity and capabilities.

author: Heather Gunderlock
text:
Morning, 
Can anyone recommend a best practice guideline/rule-of-thumb re: the percentage of time an employer should ask its employee base to devote to training/professional development? I'd be grateful for any info you may provide; thanks!
title: Professional development
